course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Time Series Analysis and Forecasting
course.description: Review of regression and its application to forecasting problems; moving averages, exponential smoothing, Box-Jenkins, ARIMA models and transfer function models; forecasts of economic, financial and business time series.
course.prerequisites: ISOM 2500 or MATH 2411
course.exclusions: ECON 4304, MATH 4425

reviews.author: V.lylit
reviews.comment_content:
The course is separated into 3 parts, in which each title is 1 lecture. Parts 1 and 2 are assessed in the 1st exam (aka midterm), and part 3 in the second exam. It looks like a heck lot of stuff, but you'll be fine as long as you attend the classes and know how to use Minitab.

Part 1: Univariate methods
1. Introduction
2. Simple smoothing methods (SMA/ exponential smoothing)
3. Decomposition methods
4. Holt's and Winters' methods

Part 2: Regression method
5. Fitting equation to data
6. Simple regression model (R-square and RMSE)
7. Intro to multiple regression model
8. Inference for multiple regression model
9. Meaning of regression coefficients
10. Variable selection techniques
11. Model selection in regression
12. Residual analysis
13. Autocorrelated errors in regression

Part 3: Box-Jenkins
14. Introduction and memory function
15. ARMA models
16. Identification of ARMA models
17. ARIMA models and their identification
18. (continued)
19. From ARMA to better models
20. Estimation and diagnostic checking
21. Forecasting with ARIMA models
22. Modelling seasonal data
23. Intervention analysis
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Hu deserves an A grade here because his lectures were a good balance of conceptual and application-related things, and he presented the contents very clearly. He's also infinitely patient with our queries, even the lazy/ brainless ones like "can you explain this slide again".

This course has tutorials which are NOT COMPULSORY and UNRELATED TO THE ASSESSMENTS, but I went there nonetheless because the teaching materials as uploaded seemed to be helpful for the assignments.

Unfortunately the tutor (for us it was Rong NIE) was barely able to speak in English, or loudly enough for the first two rows in LSK G021 to hear her, and then she wasn't teaching the relevant stuff most of the time. For example, she used 3 tutorial sessions, all of them over 1hr 20 minutes because somehow she wasn't aware that the tutorials are supposed to only last 50 minutes, to teach sequential SS... which nobody ever needed in the lectures, assignments and exams. Google it if you're interested, I'm not explaining it here.

This is also why I gave a B rating overall because I have a suspicion that next semester they'll have a different tutor... I mean, I wasn't the only one writing a huge rant about her in the SFQ...
reviews.comment_grading:
7 assignments - 15%
1st exam - 40%
2nd exam - 45%

Some of the assignments are in groups, and others are individual-based. As for the exams, they're both in class, and you're allowed to bring in an A4-sized, two-sided cheatsheet which Prof. Hu suggests that you do not directly copy the lecture slides. The recommendation makes sense because otherwise you're either copying too many words, or too many unrelated graphs.

A funky grade policy: if your final exam score sees a great improvement from the midterm's result, you can apply for shifting the entire weight of midterm to final (i.e. midterm weight --> 0%, final --> 85%!). This policy cannot be applied in the opposite direction - I asked Prof. Hu, and he said no, but he said he'll consider the fact that I participated in class :P so yea.

I got 23/24 in the midterm, and 19/24 in the final (which is why I asked if the grade policy can be applied vice versa haha). And then I got around 18-20/ 20 in all the assignments. Eventually I got an A... I think the grading is pretty decent. (and I think he has already considered my participation in class even if it's not actually graded haha)

Side note 1: not sure about the future semesters, but the exams are a lot more conceptual than the lecture, and the assignments are a lot more hands-on than the lecture... so that counts as two sides of the same knowledge you'll get. It's great to be able to understand and then apply the concepts, but not so nice if you're only strong at one facet but not the other.

Side note 2: remember to do the sample exams he puts onto canvas! It's significantly similar to the actual thing. (You can use the samples however you want, but I used the samples as diagnostics before I start revising for the exams, and I got around 16/23 for both samples.)
reviews.comment_workload:
Your workload is highly dependent on the quality of groupmates you choose, and how much you know Minitab.

With that said, the "Stat" tab will be very useful because it contains most of the things you'll need for doing the assignments. Also if you can't get the real software on your laptop, you can try using virtual barn, but the best is to do it in the actual barn because virtual barn freezes all the time if you use excel + Minitab at the same time.

Good luck finding your groupmates, and look for people who usually go to class and can read English properly... or be prepared to do the same homework 3 or 4 times to demonstrate how much bullshit they've got in their heads.

reviews.author: lmk
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly two parts. The first part is about regression. The second part is about ARMA model which is far more difficult.

The content is useful if you want to do data analytics role. Time series modeling is important as most of the financial and business data is in time series order.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Hu, Inchi is a very great professor. He is patient to answer student questions and he is passionate about his teaching. His notes are well-organised and he can explain it logically.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade. If you get average in mt and final, you can have B. The exam is testing the concept so no memorization is needed. However, in the second part regarding the ARMA model, it is quite challenging which I think need some statistic background for better understanding.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is okay for a 4 credit course. There are 7 assignments total and 4 of them are done in group. Hence the workload is mainly depend whether you have good teammates. The assignment mainly need the lecture concepts and the tutor help which is not very difficult, usually not more than 5 question each. The average is around 80%.

reviews.author: antgod
reviews.comment_content:
Part I: Univariate methods
Part II: Regression method
Part III: Box Jenkins method

The part 3 is similar to ISOM 4530.

The midterm exam (40%) covers Parts I & II;
an in class, closed book, written exam approximately one hour long.

The final exam (45%) covers Part III; similar format to the midterm exam.

Alternative weight scheme: midterm exam (20%)+ final exam (65%)

Assignments (15%) are given every one to two weeks. There are two types
of assignments: individual based and group projects, where students work
in groups.

Maximum of two weight schemes is used to calculate your combine score
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very responsible.
Willing to answer the question from student.
Very slow speed
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term: 27/30 (Mean: 23.5,High: 30,Low: 14)
Final : 23/32 (Mean: 18.61,High: 31,Low: 6)
Grade: A-

Do the practice exam before the exam. The format is very similar to the real exam.
Final exam covers the content after the mid-term, ie Part III: Box Jenkins method. The content is much harder than  Part I: Univariate methods
and Part II: Regression method.

The grading is quite good.
reviews.comment_workload:
7 assignments
3 individual
4 group

One tutorial per week, which cover the usage of minitab. The workload is similar to the 3 credit course.

reviews.author: ANormalPerson
reviews.comment_content:
1. Univariate Methods
2. Regression Methods
3. Box-Jenkins Methods

Three ways to deal with time series, but to be fair the regression methods should be taught in other statistics / OM classes already.

Before the course I expected the full course to be of (3), but somehow the professor decided to pack all these difficult contents into the final few lessons, where there was totally inadequate time for him to explain the concepts clearly.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is passionate and always carry a smile, but to be fair some of the slides are inadequate with confusing notations.

He used all x, y, z, three different variable names to represent the realizations of time series values in different lectures and different equations. Sometimes a new symbol pops up out of nowhere. This makes understanding and revision immensely hard. I understand the equations may have come from different textbooks but it would be a much nicer gesture to try to modify the equation to avoid such confusion.

It is also weird that he sometimes chooses to explain simple algebra, like moving terms from the left to right sides in an equation, rather than using the complex equations and what each term represents in those equations.

You can go to the lab where the TA teaches the software.
reviews.comment_workload:
Okay workload. 7 assignments in total, 3 individual and 4 group ones. Really helps consolidate your concept well.

I knew the software beforehand so I did not go to the lab sessions.
